Demographics.name: Demographics
Demographics.description: Contains patient/enrollee level descriptives for the people found in VDW tables.  It serves as a lookup dataset for MRNs.  Every MRN appearing in any other VDW file should appear in the Demographics table, even if demographics information on the person is unknown.

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Unique to each patient at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Used to link people across files within a site. May or may not contain the official local indigenous person identifier (e.g., 'medical record number').

columns.name: birth_date
columns.definition: The person's date of birth
columns.valid_values: Any SAS Date

columns.name: sex_admin
columns.definition: The person's 'administrative sex'–the value stored in official/legacy sources at last ascertainment
implementation_guidelines: Legacy sources may designate the information we mean here as either 'sex' or 'gender' without regard for the distinction between these concepts. In the absence of specific knowledge that a given legacy source codes gender identity, implementers should default to placing legacy data in this variable.
In general, any data collected before your organization began collecting detailed SOGI data should go in this field.
The workgroup expects that sex_admin will be most similar to the existing gender field in terms of having informative values on >99% of records and will be the best single-field substitute for it.
This is not compatible with PHVS_AdministrativeSex_HL7_2x but should better accomodate the data we expect to be available at the sites.

columns.name: sex_at_birth
columns.definition: The person's sex as assigned at birth.

valid_values.meaning: Uncertain, Unknown or Not recorded on birth certificate

implementation_guidelines: The existence of the ‘Intersex’ and ‘Other’ options renders this incompatible with LOINC LL3324-2. Those values appear in our data and are foreseeably useful enough to research that we are comfortable departing from LOINC compatibility.
It is expected that sex_admin may change over time as a person changes their legal and/or physical sex–this variable should not change.
Missing values should be coded as Unknown.

columns.name: gender_identity
columns.definition: The person’s gender identity as subjectively experienced, on last ascertainment.

valid_values.meaning: Genderqueer or non-conforming or non-binary or genderfluid

implementation_guidelines: Values of ‘unsure/questioning’ should be coded as Other.
Missing values should be coded as Unknown.

columns.name: Race1-Race5
columns.definition: The person's race. Preference is for self-reported; please see comment 1 for recording multiple race values

valid_values.meaning: Other, values that do not fit well in any other value

columns.implementation_guidelines: See comments below.

columns.name: Hispanic
columns.definition: Whether the person is of Hispanic origin / ethnicity

columns.name: needs_interpreter
columns.definition: Whether the person needs an interpreter to communicate with an English-only speaker
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable is capable of changing over time. Populate with only the most recently known interpreter status.

comments.title: MRNs should be People
comments.comment: Sites should do their best to maintain a 1:1 correspondence between people and MRNs. Fictitious/test numbers should be removed from the VDW. People with > 1 assigned MRN should be merged into a single number (in all files).

comments.title: Hispanic ethnicity reported as race
comments.comment: If source data indicates the person's race as 'Hispanic' and there is no other known race recorded for the person, code the person's race as unknown.

comments.title: Recommended Mappings
comments.comment: Please see appendix A for guidelines on mapping local race values to the permissible value set listed above.

comments.title: Multiple Race Values
comments.comment: When more than one race is known for a given person, assign values to the race variables in the order listed above (HP, IN, AS, BA, WH, MU, OT, UN). Fill in any unused race variables with the value UN for unknown / not reported. Examples of coding RACE1 through RACE5 are illustrated here:

Enrollments.name: Enrollments
Enrollments.description: The ENROLLMENT table contains periods of time during which we believe to have at least the partial capture of medical care information, either because of enrollment in a health plan or as a patient of a care delivery system that the implementing site owns or interacts with. Insurance coverage is not the only basis of data capture (see ENROLLMENT_BASIS) nor do all records necessarily indicate completeness of data capture (see the capture warning variables, which all begin with 'incomplete_'). Each record represents a period of time during which the information on the included variables was true. As many records as are necessary should be added to represent changes over time. There may be many contiguous records for a single period of enrollment, in order to account for these changes.

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Unique to each patient at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Used to link people across files within a site. May or may not contain the official local indigenous person identifier (e.g., 'medical record number').

columns.name: enr_start
columns.definition: Beginning of the period at risk for medical care capture
columns.valid_values: SAS Date
columns.implementation_guidelines: Sites with exact date information on starts/stops should use them; those that do not should use the first and last days of the month. Periods that are ongoing at the time the file is created should bear the last day of known, actual enrollment at the time of the update. E.g. if source data if realtime, enr_end would be set to &sysdate but is source data is updated weekly, enr_end would be the last day of the week prior to the update.

columns.name: enr_end
columns.definition: End of the period at risk for medical care capture
columns.valid_values: SAS Date

columns.name: PCC
columns.definition: The primary care clinic to which the patient is paneled in the administrative record.
columns.valid_values: Values link as a foreign key to Facility.facility_code.

columns.name: PCP
columns.definition: The primary care physician to which the patient is paneled in the administrative record.
columns.valid_values: Values link as a foreign key to Provider.provider.

columns.name: enrollment_basis
columns.definition: The basis for the claim that we have at least partial capture of the medical care information during the period.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Historically Insurance was the only permissible basis. This was expanded as HCSRN took on new member organizations which were pure providers of health care and had no insurance function.

columns.name: incomplete_outpt_rx
columns.definition: Is outpatient pharmacy fill data suspected to be incomplete for this person/period?

valid_values.meaning: There are known reasons to suspect incomplete capture
No, there is no known reason to suspect incomplete capture
This variable not implemented at this site

columns.name: incomplete_outpt_enc
columns.definition: Is outpatient encounter data suspected to be incomplete for this person/period?

valid_values.meaning: There are known reasons to suspect incomplete capture
No, there is no known reason to suspect incomplete capture
This variable not implemented at this site

columns.name: incomplete_inpt_enc
columns.definition: Is inpatient encounter data suspected to be incomplete for this person/period?

valid_values.meaning: There are known reasons to suspect incomplete capture
No, there is no known reason to suspect incomplete capture
This variable not implemented at this site

columns.name: incomplete_emr
columns.definition: Is electronic medical record (e.g., social history, vital signs) data suspected to be incomplete for this person/period?

valid_values.meaning: There are known reasons to suspect incomplete capture
No, there is no known reason to suspect incomplete capture
This variable not implemented at this site

columns.name: incomplete_tumor
columns.definition: Is tumor data suspected to be incomplete for this person/period?

valid_values.meaning: There are known reasons to suspect incomplete capture
No, there is no known reason to suspect incomplete capture
This variable not implemented at this site

columns.name: incomplete_lab
columns.definition: Is lab results data suspected to be incomplete for this person/period?

valid_values.meaning: There are known reasons to suspect incomplete capture
No, there is no known reason to suspect incomplete capture
This variable not implemented at this site

columns.name: ins_medicaid
columns.definition: Whether the person had any Medicaid insurance coverage during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines: See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_commercial
columns.definition: Whether the person had any commercial insurance coverage during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines: See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_privatepay
columns.definition: Whether the person had any insurance coverage in a private pay plan during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Broadly defined as the individual bearing nearly all of the cost of the premium.

See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_statesubsidized
columns.definition: Whether the person had any state subsidized insurance coverage during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Typically covers lower income individuals who do not qualify for Medicaid.

See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_selffunded
columns.definition: Whether the person had any insurance coverage through an employer group that insures itself during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Typically commercial employers who bear employee's medical risk. The HMO serves as a claims administrator.

See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_highdeductible
columns.definition: Whether the person had any insurance coverage in a high deductible plan during the period as defined by the U.S. IRS (Pub 969) qualifying for a Health Savings Account

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines: See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_medicare
columns.definition: Whether the person had any Medicare insurance coverage, including Medicare working aged, during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

If any ins_medicare_X variables are set to 'Y', this variable should also equal 'Y'.

columns.name: ins_medicare_a
columns.definition: Whether the person had any Medicare Part A insurance coverage, including Medicare working aged, during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Part A generally covers inpatient care.

See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_medicare_b
columns.definition: Whether the person had any Medicare Part B insurance coverage, including Medicare working aged, during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Part B generally covers outpatient care.

See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_medicare_c
columns.definition: Whether the person had any Medicare Part C insurance coverage, including Medicare working aged, during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Part C generally covers inpatient and outpatient but with capitated payment to the insurance provider.

See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_medicare_d
columns.definition: Whether the person had any Medicare Part D insurance coverage, including Medicare working aged, during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Part D generally covers prescription drugs.

See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: ins_other
columns.definition: Whether the person had insurance coverage during the period that is not otherwise included in the INS_* variables during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Any other insurance type not adequetely categorized by one of the other INS_* variables.

See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each insurance coverage.

columns.name: plan_hmo
columns.definition: Whether the person had insurance coverage under an HMO plan during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines: See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each plan type.

columns.name: plan_pos
columns.definition: Whether the person had insurance coverage under a point-of-service plan during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines: See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each plan type.

columns.name: plan_ppo
columns.definition: Whether the person had insurance coverage under a Preferred Provider Organization plan during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines: See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each plan type.

columns.name: plan_indemnity
columns.definition: Whether the person had insurance coverage under a traditional indemnity plan during the period

valid_values.meaning: Yes, but from an External organization

columns.implementation_guidelines: See Appendix B for detailed descriptions of each plan type.

Enrollments.primary_key: MRN + ENR_START (no overlapping time periods are permitted)

comments.title: Capture Warning (INCOMPLETE_XXX) Variables
comments.comment: For the INCOMPLETE_XXX variables, users are advised to treat N and X values as essentially identical in information content.  For applications that require, for example, complete Tumor data over time, we recommend using a condition like:  WHERE incomplete_tumor ne 'K'.  Users may also want to avail themselves of the enrollment_basis variable for applications that require complete pharmacy or encounter data.  When in doubt please check with your sites.

comments.title: No Overlapping Periods
comments.comment: There may be many contiguous records for a single period of enrollment, in order to account for changes in the substantive variables. However, periods must not overlap one another; there should be only one record covering any given day + medical record number. Discussion and code on how to implement non-overlapping periods is available on the HCSRN website. The following graphic depicts how data should be split out into multiple records.

Languages.name: Patient Languages
Languages.description: The LANGUAGE table contains information on the languages that patients speak and write. There is one record per person per known language. People on whom you have no language information should not be included in the table.

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Unique to each patient at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Used to link people across files within a site. May or may not contain the official local indigenous person identifier (e.g., 'medical record number').

columns.name: lang_iso
columns.definition: A code signifying the language.
columns.valid_values: As defined by ISO-639-2 or 'unk' for unknown.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Note that value set is lowercase.

columns.name: lang_usage
columns.definition: How the person uses this language.

columns.name: lang_primary
columns.definition: For spoken languages, whether this is the person's primary spoken language.

comments.title: Only Known Languages
comments.comment: People for which you have no language information should not be included in this table.

Facility.name: Facility Lookup
Facility.description: Contains the most recent information about each health care facility found in the implementing site's VDW tables.

columns.name: facility_code
columns.definition: An implementing-site-unique identifier of a health care facility
columns.valid_values: Any non-null value
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Must be unique and never missing.

Length and contents should match all other instances of this field.

columns.name: relationship
columns.definition: Relationship between the facility and the implementing site.

valid_values.meaning: Owned and/or operated by your health care organization.
External facility.  A facility NOT owned nor operated by your health care organization.  Includes contract facilities.

columns.implementation_guidelines: See comment 1 below.

columns.name: relationship_history
columns.definition: Describes the relationhship history between the facility and your health care organization.

valid_values.meaning: Always owned and/or operated by your health care organization.
Always an external facility (includes contract facilities).
Was an owned facility, most recently an external facility
Was an external facility, most recently an owned facility

columns.implementation_guidelines: See comment 1 below.

columns.name: address_facility_type
columns.definition: Specify whether the address information is for a clinical or billing location
columns.implementation_guidelines: If both types of locations are known, include only the Clinical location. Populate only if at least Zip code is known.

columns.name: full_address
columns.definition: Full address of the facility
columns.valid_values: Street address, city, state, zip combined in to one variable, or null.
columns.implementation_guidelines: A concatenation of the address component variables that follow, for sites that don't have them parsed out in indigenous data.

columns.name: street_address
columns.definition: Street address of the facility.
columns.valid_values: Any, including null.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Use the street address for the clinical location if possible.  If not, then use the billing facility address. This field is populated if the information is readily available in indigenous data.

columns.name: city
columns.definition: City where the facility is located
columns.valid_values: Any city name, or null.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This field is populated if the information is readily available in the source system.

columns.name: state
columns.definition: State where the facility is located
columns.valid_values: Any valid State or Province abbreviation, or null
columns.implementation_guidelines: This field is populated if the information is easily available in the source system.

columns.name: zip
columns.definition: Zip code of the facility (5 or 9 digits) or null.
columns.valid_values:
5 or 9 digit zip code, with leading zeroes, and no dashes, or null.

For example:
01234
12345
123456789
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Retain leading zeroes, but do not pad out 5 digit source values with additional leading or trailing zeroes. For example:
  • source value of '01234' remains '01234'
  • source value of '12345' remains '12345' not '123450000' or '000012345'

columns.name: latitude
columns.definition: latitude of the location in degrees
columns.valid_values: Real numbers between -90 and 90, or missing.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Generally obtained by geocoding the address indicated in the foregoing fields.

columns.name: longitude
columns.definition: longitude of the location in degrees
columns.valid_values: Real numbers between -90 and 90, or missing.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Generally obtained by geocoding the address indicated in the foregoing fields.

comments.title: Relationship of Facility to Implementing Site
comments.comment:
Implementers at HMOs typically have data on care ocurring both internal to their health system, and outside of it (from submitted claims). There are two major implications of this internal/external distinction.

First, health plans typically have more control on the type, volume, quality, and cost of care at the facilities that they own and/or operate. There is a stronger incentive to provide efficient care and providers at these facilities probably have access to more complete patient information. Health plans typically have less control over external facilities. These external facilities often have different incentives and thus, care patterns may be different. For instance, the mom delivery C-section rate may be different at owned hospitals as compared to external hospitals. Despite the disadvantages, it's also possible that patients may receive better care at an external facility (the specialty group with the best reputation in the service area may be at an external facility).

Second, facility locations indicated on incoming claims may only include the billing location--where payment should be submited.

comments.title: Prefer Clinical Locations
comments.comment: A common application for this table is estimating the distance patients must travel in order to obtain care. For that reason we always prefer to have the locations where care takes place (clinical locations) rather than the locations to which payments should be submitted (billing locations).

Providers.name: Providers
Providers.description: The PROVIDER table contains proivder level descriptives for the providers found in VDW tables.  Every provider appearing in any other VDW file should appear in the PROVIDER table, even if demographics information is unknown.

columns.name: provider
columns.definition: The unique provider identifier.
columns.valid_values: Any unique non-null value.

columns.name: specialty
columns.definition: The provider's specialty.
columns.valid_values: One of the values given in Appendix C.
columns.implementation_guidelines:
If multiple specialties are known and the provider's current primary specialty is known, put the primary/current specialty in this variable.

See recommended mappings on the HCSRN portal.

columns.name: specialty2-specialtyN
columns.definition: Optional variables (as many as desired) to indicate when a provider has multiple specialties.
columns.valid_values: One of the values given in Appendix C: Provider Specialties.

columns.name: provider_type
columns.definition: The position, job, title, or role of the provider.
columns.valid_values: One of the values given in Appendix C:Provider Types.

columns.name: provider_birth_year
columns.definition: The year that the provider was born.
columns.valid_values: Any integer > 1800, or null if unknown

columns.name: year_graduated
columns.definition: The year that the provider graduated from medical/nursing/technical school.
columns.valid_values: Any integer > 1800, or null if unknown

columns.name: provider_gender
columns.definition: The provider's gender and/or sex;  if both gender and sex are known, this variable holds gender.

columns.name: provider_race
columns.definition: The provider's race
columns.valid_values: As defined in race1 in the Demographics specification.

columns.name: provider_hispanic
columns.definition: The provider's ethnicity
columns.valid_values: As defined in hispanic in the Demographics specification.

comments.title: Providers should be People
comments.comment: Sites should do their best to maintain a 1:1 correspondence between people and provider values. To the extent practical, people assigned > 1 provider value should be merged into a single record/value to be used in all VDW files with provider columns.

comments.title: Only a single specialty variable is guaranteed to exist
comments.comment: In defiance of God and VDW convention, the numbered-suffix specialty vars may not exist at all at a given implementing site.

Utilization.name: Utilization: Encounters
Utilization.description: The ENCOUNTER table contains one record for each significant medical-related interaction between a patient and a medical provider, regardless of care setting or type of encounter. All known encounters should be included whether known through claims, through clinical systems, or a third source type. Inclusion, exclusions, classification, and uniqueness of an encounter is dependent on the type of service and care setting. For a precise description, please refer to the Utilization Implementation Guidelines on the private HCSRN website.

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Unique to each patient at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Used to link people across files within a site. May or may not contain the official local indigenous person identifier (e.g., 'medical record number').

columns.name: adate
columns.definition: Encounter or admit date for inpatient or institutional stay.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date
columns.implementation_guidelines: If encounter/admit date is unknown, then use the first date of a claim.

columns.name: provider
columns.definition: Identifies the provider most responsible for the encounter.
columns.valid_values: Values link as a foreign key to Provider.provider.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Usually a physician, nurse practitioner, physician assistant, optometrist, etc.

columns.name: facility_code
columns.definition: A code indiciating the facility, hospital, or clinic in which the encounter occurred.
columns.valid_values: Values link as a foreign key to Facility.facility_code.

columns.name: enctype
columns.definition: The type of encounter

valid_values.meaning: Acute inpatient hospital stay including inpatient stays, same-day hospital discharges, hospital transfers when patient was admitted into hospital, acute inpatient pysch, and detox stays. [SUB = AI]
Emergency department excluding urgent care [SUB = HA, OC]

Ambulatory visit including outpatient clinics, same-day surgeries, observation beds, urgent care visits, and same-day ambulatory hospital encounters. Excludes emergency department. [SUB = OC, OB, SD, HA, UC, RH, DI, OT]
Non-acute institutional stays including hospice, SNF, rehab, nursing home, residential, overnight non-hospital dialysis and other non-hospital stays [SUB = HS, SN, NH, RH, DI, OT]

Other Encounters:  Non-overnight hospice visits, home health visits, SNF visits, or other visits that do not occur in a typical ambulatory clinic or hospital setting.  This encounter type can include individual professional services or provider rounding visits for inpatient or institutional stays where no facility claim could be identified in which to merge these visits.    [Encounter_subtype=HS, HH, SN, RH, DI, OT, AI, NH]
A lab only encounter that cannot be matched to another encounter [SUB = OC, OT]
A radiology only encounter that cannot be matched to another encounter [SUB = OC, OT]

Virtual Care - an encounter that takes place by phone, video, chat, online portal or another type of non-face to face mechanism.  Can include synchronous or asychronous contact. [SUB= CH, EM, OA, OI, OT, PP, TC, TN, TS, VV]

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Only certain combinations of enctype and encounter_subtype values are permitted--see the bracketed lists of subtypes permitted with each enctype (and vice-versa).

Implementers should include as many of these types of encounters as are available in indigenous data. Users should not assume that all encounter types are available at all implementing sites.

columns.name: encounter_subtype
columns.definition: Further specification of the type of encounter. Valid associated ENCTYPE values are in brackets.

valid_values.meaning: Acute inpatient stay excluding observation bed [TYPE=IP, OE]
Hospital ambulatory; outpatient care at hospital excluding same-day surgery and observation beds [TYPE = AV, ED]
Nursing home including intermediate care facilities [TYPE = IS, OE]
Outpatient clinic visit [TYPE = AV, LO, RO, ED]
Provider to Provider/Facility to Facility Virtual Care [TYPE=VC]
Other non-hospital [TYPE = IS, OE, AV, LO, RO, VC]

columns.implementation_guidelines: Only certain combinations of enctype and encounter_subtype values are permitted--see the bracketed lists of types permitted with each subtype (and vice-versa).

columns.name: enc_id
columns.definition: An arbitrary, static, unique encounter identifier.
columns.valid_values: Any non-null value, so long as they uniquely identify an encounter.
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Should not be changed across updates.

This is a surrogate key. The natural key is mrn, provider, facility_code, adate, atime, enctype, and encounter_subtype.

columns.name: atime
columns.definition: Start time of the encounter.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS time value, or null if unknown
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Use admission time for inpatient, emergency or institutional encounters.

For other encounters (such as ambulatory visits), use check-in time if this field is populated, otherwise use appointment time.

columns.name: ddate
columns.definition: Discharge date for inpatient and overnight encounters, or encounter end date if otherwise available in source data
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date value, or null if unknown/not applicable
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Expected to be populated for inpatient and institutional stays.

If precise discharge date is unknown, use the date of the last claim for the encounter.

columns.name: dtime
columns.definition: Discharge or end time of the encounter.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS time value, or null if unknown
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Use discharge time for inpatient, emergency or institutional encounters.

For other encounters (such as ambulatory visits), use check-out time if this field is populated.

columns.name: drg_value
columns.definition: The Diagnostic Related Group value. Used for hospital encounters.
columns.valid_values: Numeric codes as defined by <abbr title='Centers for Medicare and Medicaid'>CMS</abbr> or other relevant authority (determined by drg_version).
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Expected to be populated on inpatient [IP] and institutional stay [IS] encounters, but populate for all encounters when known.

Use leading zeros for codes less than 100.

columns.name: drg_version
columns.definition: Version of the value in drg_value.
columns.implementation_guidelines: The admit-date border between the earlier CMS-DRG scheme and the subsequent MS-DRG scheme is 01-oct-2007.

columns.name: admitting_source
columns.definition: The location from which the patient was admitted for events with admit.

columns.name: discharge_status
columns.definition: The status of the patient at discharge for events with discharge.

columns.name: discharge_disposition
columns.definition: The disposition of the patient at discharge for events with discharge.

columns.name: dept
columns.definition: The department where the encounter took place
columns.valid_values: As given in Appendix A2: Dept Values
columns.implementation_guidelines:
This is not necessarily the specialty of the clinician providing services.

If department information is unavailable in the source data (as may happen in claims data), specify as 'UNKNWN'.

See New 6 Character DEPARTMENT values, Appendix A2

columns.name: source_data
columns.definition: Classification of the database that was used to create this record.

valid_values.meaning: Your site's EHR (Electronic Health Record) operated by your health care organization. Excludes claims and billing data.

Billing data--for services performed by your organization and captured in your org's EHR, but formatted for billing an outside insurer. These are sometimes referred to as 'internal' or 'outgoing' claims, or transaction data.
Claims data--for services performed outside of your health care organization, presented to your organization for payment as the patient's insurer.
Local data source but unrelated to your site's EHR . Often Includes pre-EHR systems prior to EHR implementation such as appointment management systems.
Multiple sources--the encounter is an amalgam of data from different sources (e.g., inpatient encounters with data from claims and EHR rounding)
Other. Not from the sources listed above.

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Category 'E' includes:
  • Direct extract from your site's EHR (or associated reporting database).
  • A secondary database that houses your site's EHR data (no code changes for billing)
  • Data for services captured in other local systems (such as a separate lab or radiology system) and interfaced into your site's EHR.

columns.name: electronic_chart_review
columns.definition: Can this encounter be chart reviewed electronically?

valid_values.meaning:
Partially (part of the record can be reviewed electronically). A couple of examples:
  • If only a discharge summary is available for inpatient stays
  • if only rounding data is available for inpatient stays

comments.title: What is an encounter?
comments.comment: In general, the intention of the encounter file is to describe all significant interactions between patients and medical providers. It should include such things as inpatient stays, emergency department visits,  other outpatient hospital services (e.g. same day surgeries), ambulatory visits, home health encounters, and non-hospital residential stays including skilled nursing facility, rehab, nursing home, overnight hospice facility, and overnight dialysis facility.

comments.title: Uniquely Identifying an Encounter
comments.comment: A single inpatient stay, non-acute institutional stay (such as SNF, Rehab, Nursing Home, overnight Hospice or Dialysis stay) or emergency visit has 1 record in the encounter file.  For ambulatory visit, telephone, e-mail, lab only, radiology only and 'other' encounters, a unique encounter record is defined as each patient and provider medical contact documented in the source data (exclude scheduling appointments and other administrative tasks). A unique combination of the following variables is an encounter:  MRN, adate, enctype, encounter_subtype, provider, facility_code, and atime (if available).

comments.title: What types of encounters should be included?
comments.comment: See the definition of the variables EncType and Encounter_Subtype for the full list of the types of encounters that should be included.  Questions about whether a particular type of encounter should be included and how it should be characterized should be directed to the VDW Utilization Workgroup.

comments.title: Members only?
comments.comment: Data on all services provided by the health plan, whether or not they were provided to a member (enrollee) of the plan should be included.  (This means that this file will frequently need to be checked against Enrollment in order to identify study populations-users should not assume that people found in the Utilization tables are members of the health plan, or that anything in particular is known about them.)

comments.title: Internally provided services only?
comments.comment: All available encounters should be included, even those taking place at external providers (in other words, claims data should be included if that is the only source you have for a given encounter).  Sites with known data 'blind spots' (e.g., hospice care is subcontracted out on a capitated basis, and no claims are submitted) should document them on their Utilization implementation page on the CRN Portal.

Diagnoses.name: Utilization: Diagnoses
Diagnoses.description: The DIAGNOSIS table contains all recorded diagnoses associated with the encounters indicated in the ENCOUNTERS table with the exception of admitting diagnoses for inpatient stays.

columns.name: enc_id
columns.definition: An arbitrary, static, unique encounter identifier.
columns.valid_values: Foreign key to utilization.enc_id

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Must match value on corresponding record in utilization.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable's redundancy is to improve querying performance.

columns.name: adate
columns.definition: Encounter date.
columns.valid_values: Must match value on corresponding record in utilization.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable's redundancy is to improve querying performance.

columns.name: provider
columns.definition: Identifies the provider most responsible for the encounter.
columns.valid_values: Must match value on corresponding record in utilization.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable's redundancy is to improve querying performance.

columns.name: enctype
columns.definition: Type of encounter at which this diagnosis was made.
columns.valid_values: Must match value on corresponding record in utilization.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable's redundancy is to improve querying performance.

columns.name: diagprovider
columns.definition: Identifies the provider that made the diagnosis.
columns.valid_values: Values link as a foreign key to Provider.provider.
columns.implementation_guidelines: If unknown, set the value equal to the PROVIDER variable.

columns.name: dx
columns.definition: The diagnosis code
columns.valid_values: Any valid value per the scheme named in dx_codetype below. Cannot be null.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Any alpha characters should be converted to UPPERCASE.

columns.name: dx_codetype
columns.definition: The coding set used in the DX variable for this record.

columns.name: origdx
columns.definition: The diagnosis code as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning.
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: May include nonstandard prefixes/suffixes that signify site-specific refinements on the standard code.

columns.name: principal_dx
columns.definition: For hospital admissions, whether this diagnosis is the principal discharge diagnosis of the encounter. The principal diagnosis indicates the main reason why the patient was admitted to the hospital for care and the value on which a DRG is assigned.
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Assigned after discharge after review by the medical record department, the principal diagnosis is main reason why the patient was admitted to the hospital for care. This is the diagnosis on which the DRG is based. Note that the principal diagnosis is very different from the admitting diagnosis which is assigned at the beginning of the stay. For example, if a patient was admitted to a hospital with an admitting diagnosis of chest pain which was later diagnosed as a heart attack during the stay, the principal diagnosis would be heart attack.

Specify principal diagnosis as defined by the site’s institutional source data. It is expected that there should be one and only one principal diagnosis per hospitalization. For claims systems, the principal diagnosis may be found in the UB facility bill (field number 67 in UB 92 and UB 04 or '2300 HI01-2' on the electronic form) which should be the first diagnosis code listed. If there are multiple UB facility bills for a stay, identify the principal diagnosis from the final/last facility bill. If there are multiple final bills on the last date, use the one with the longest LOS. While the value 'P' is expected to only be specified for inpatient and institutional stays, it is allowed for other encounter types if it is clearly identified in the source data. However in most typical cases for other encounters, the principal_dx should be set to 'N'. If the source data does not identify principal diagnosis (or not principal) for specific inpatient and institutional stays, then set Principal_dx to 'X' for all diagnoses.

columns.name: primary_dx
columns.definition: Whether this diagnosis is the primary diagnosis of the encounter. The primary diagnosis is the most serious or resource intensive diagnosis and is the primary reason for the procedures being rendered.
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Primary diagnosis is the illness or injury that was the most serious/severe/life-threatening and/or resource intensive. From a claims perspective, it is the main reason for a provider's services being rendered (and billed/paid for). Multiple primary diagnoses are allowed if the final/last professional claim can't be determined using the criteria above or if the primary diagnosis was a local combination code that has to be put into multiple records to have values within a standard coding system.

Specify primary diagnosis as defined by the site's institutional source data. For an outpatient encounter, it is expected that there should be one and only one primary diagnosis. For an inpatient stay, there can be multiple primary diagnoses, one for each provider claim during the stay. A provider may have multiple claims during a stay, each with a primary diagnosis. If multiple bills were submitted for a claim, choose the final/last professional bill. For claims systems, the primary diagnosis may be found in the HCFA professional bill (field number 21.1 in the HCFA 1500 or '2400 SV107-1' in the electronic form) which is the first diagnosis code listed. The other diagnoses on this bill should be identified as 'S' (Secondary Dx). The values 'P' (Primary Dx) and 'S' (Secondary Dx) should only be specified for encounters where there's a clearly defined primary diagnosis in the source data. Thus, if the source data does not identify primary or secondary diagnoses for a specific encounter, then set all diagnoses for that encounter to 'X' (Not Classifiable). If all diagnoses for an encounter are reported as secondary in the source data, then set primary_dx='S' (Secondary DX).

Multiple primary diagnoses are allowed if the final/last professional claim can't be determined using the criteria above or if the primary diagnosis was a local combination code that has to be put into multiple records to have values within a standard coding system.

columns.name: source_data_dx
columns.definition: Classification of the database that was used to create this record.

valid_values.meaning: Your site's EHR (Electronic Health Record) operated by your health care organization. Excludes claims and billing data.

Billing data--for services performed by your organization and captured in your org's EHR, but formatted for billing an outside insurer. These are sometimes referred to as 'internal' or 'outgoing' claims, or transaction data.
Claims data--for services performed outside of your health care organization, presented to your organization for payment as the patient's insurer.
Local data source but unrelated to your site's EHR . Often Includes pre-EHR systems prior to EHR implementation such as appointment management systems.
Multiple sources--the encounter is an amalgam of data from different sources (e.g., inpatient encounters with data from claims and EHR rounding)
Other. Not from the sources listed above.

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Need not match the corresponding value in utilization.source_data.

Category 'E' includes:
  • Direct extract from your site's EHR (or associated reporting database).
  • A secondary database that houses your site's EHR data (no code changes for billing)
  • Data for services captured in other local systems (such as a separate lab or radiology system) and interfaced into your site's EHR.

comments.title: DO include
comments.comment: Diagnoses from professional and inpatient rounding services.

comments.title: Do NOT include
comments.comment: Admitting diagnoses for inpatient stays, or diagnoses from <abbr title='Electronic Health Record'>EHR</abbr> Problem Lists.

Procedures.name: Utilization: Procedures
Procedures.description: The PROCEDURE table contains all recorded procedures that were actually performed associated with the encounters indicated in the ENCOUNTERS table.

columns.name: enc_id
columns.definition: An arbitrary, static, unique encounter identifier.
columns.valid_values: Foreign key to utilization.enc_id

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Must match value on corresponding record in utilization.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable's redundancy is to improve querying performance.

columns.name: adate
columns.definition: Encounter date.
columns.valid_values: Must match value on corresponding record in utilization.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable's redundancy is to improve querying performance.

columns.name: procdate
columns.definition: The actual date when the procedure was performed.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date, or null
columns.implementation_guidelines: Unknown values should be coded as missing/null.

columns.name: provider
columns.definition: Identifies the provider most responsible for the encounter.
columns.valid_values: Must match value on corresponding record in utilization.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable's redundancy is to improve querying performance.

columns.name: enctype
columns.definition: Type of encounter at which this diagnosis was made.
columns.valid_values: Must match value on corresponding record in utilization.
columns.implementation_guidelines: This variable's redundancy is to improve querying performance.

columns.name: performingprovider
columns.definition: Identifies the provider that performed the procedure.
columns.valid_values: Values link as a foreign key to Provider.provider.
columns.implementation_guidelines: If unknown, set the value equal to the PROVIDER variable.

columns.name: px
columns.definition: Code identifying the procedure that was performed.
columns.valid_values: Any valid value per the scheme named in px_codetype below. Cannot be null.
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Convert local codes to standard codes if possible.

Any alpha characters should be converted to UPPERCASE.

Revenue codes may appear as both a 3-digit value and an equivalent 4-digit value with a leading zero, for example, both '123' and '0123' may appear in the data. Users should include both variants in filter/query conditions.

columns.name: px_codetype
columns.definition: The coding set used in the PX variable for this record.

columns.name: origpx
columns.definition: The procedure code as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning.
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: EMR Systems typically have unique procedure identifiers that can be linked to either ICD-9-CM or ICD-10-CM codes.  Sites should consider populating the VDW ORIGPX variable with this unique procedure identifier from their EMR source system that could allow projects to convert codes from that source into one coding system (either ICD-9-CM or ICD-10-CM).

columns.name: pxcnt
columns.definition: Number of times this procedure was performed on this procdate, by this provider, on this patient, etc.
columns.valid_values: Any integer > 0
columns.implementation_guidelines: Should always be 1 unless the procedure was performed multiple times.

columns.name: cptmod1
columns.definition: First modifier to a CPT or HCPCS procedure code used to communicate special circumstances related to the performance of a procedure.
columns.valid_values: Value set is set by the American Medical Association and proprietary

columns.name: cptmod2
columns.definition: Second modifier to a CPT or HCPCS procedure code used to communicate special circumstances related to the performance of a procedure.
columns.valid_values: Value set is set by the American Medical Association and proprietary

columns.name: cptmod3
columns.definition: Third modifier to a CPT or HCPCS procedure code used to communicate special circumstances related to the performance of a procedure.
columns.valid_values: Value set is set by the American Medical Association and proprietary

columns.name: source_data_px
columns.definition: Classification of the database that was used to create this record.

valid_values.meaning: Your site's EHR (Electronic Health Record) operated by your health care organization. Excludes claims and billing data.

Billing data--for services performed by your organization and captured in your org's EHR, but formatted for billing an outside insurer. These are sometimes referred to as 'internal' or 'outgoing' claims, or transaction data.
Claims data--for services performed outside of your health care organization, presented to your organization for payment as the patient's insurer.
Local data source but unrelated to your site's EHR . Often Includes pre-EHR systems prior to EHR implementation such as appointment management systems.
Multiple sources--the encounter is an amalgam of data from different sources (e.g., inpatient encounters with data from claims and EHR rounding)
Other. Not from the sources listed above.

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Need not match the corresponding value in utilization.source_data.

Category 'E' includes:
  • Direct extract from your site's EHR (or associated reporting database).
  • A secondary database that houses your site's EHR data (no code changes for billing)
  • Data for services captured in other local systems (such as a separate lab or radiology system) and interfaced into your site's EHR.

columns.name: source_category_px
columns.definition: Source of the procedure information.

valid_values.meaning: Order (such as from your EHR's order table)
Billing (billing data such as transaction tables and internal claims created from services inside the health care organization)
Claim (external claims for services outside the health care organization)
Other (including but not limited to your EHR's encounter table)

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Definition and specs from from PCORnet. Use to populate the PX_SOURCE variable in the PCORnet procedure table.

Order and billing pertain to internal healthcare processes and data sources. Claim pertains to data from the bill fulfillment, generally data sources held by insurers and other health plans.

Procedures.primary_key: enc_id + procdate + performingprovider + origpx + px + px_codetype + cptmod1-3

comments.title: Include
comments.comment:
Include all performed procedures from all settings including lab, radiology and immunization procedure codes.

Include procedures from professional and inpatient rounding services (outpatient providers who visit their patients in the hospital) in inpatient encounters. Identify the professional/inpatient rounding provider in the 'performingprovider' variable and the procedure date in the 'procdate' variable.

Include denied claims if you consider the utilization to be valid.

Require that the procedure file contain each type of procedure code when available: CPT, HCPCS, ICD9, Revenue Code.

comments.title: Exclude
comments.comment: Exclude procedures that were ordered but not performed.

comments.title: Orphans Are Permitted
comments.comment: Lab, radiology, immunization and other procedure codes may exist without a linked record in the encounter file.

OutpatientFills.name: Outpatient Fills
OutpatientFills.description: The PHARMACY file contains data on medications dispensed in the outpatient setting.  Dispensings in the inpatient setting are not included.

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Unique to each patient at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Used to link people across files within a site. May or may not contain the official local indigenous person identifier (e.g., 'medical record number').

columns.name: rxdate
columns.definition: Date that medication was dispensed
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date
columns.implementation_guidelines: Dispensed = Received by Member/Patient

columns.name: ndc
columns.definition: The identifier of a drug (or pharmacy product).
columns.valid_values:
Any value, but optimally a standard (US) National Drug Code.

Foreign key into the EverNDC lookup table.
columns.implementation_guidelines:
If available, this should be the National Drug Code in the HIPAA/CMS/NCPDP standard 5-4-2 configuration without dashes.

If a true NDC is not available, a locally defined unique identifier with up to 11 characters can be used.

columns.name: rxsup
columns.definition: Number of days of medication supplied
columns.valid_values: Integers > 0
columns.implementation_guidelines: Either RXSUP or RXAMT must be a positive value.

columns.name: rxamt
columns.definition: Number of units (e.g. pills, tablets) dispensed
columns.valid_values: Integers > 0
columns.implementation_guidelines: Either RXSUP or RXAMT must be a positive value.

columns.name: rxmd
columns.definition: The provider that prescribed this medication.
columns.valid_values: Values link as a foreign key to Provider.provider.

comments.title: Dealing with duplicates
comments.comment:
Primary key is under review. Rolling up data is not required by the work group at this time.

Rows are unique on the combination of patient, NDC, dispense date, and prescribing provider. When multiple dispensings occur for the same patient for the same drug on the same day from the same provider, the amount dispensed and days supplied of the drug should be summed.

comments.title: Exclude
comments.comment: Exclude incomplete or unfilled medication orders.

comments.title: Compound Drugs
comments.comment: Compound drugs may be represented differently across sites. If a drug of interest is a compound drug, users may want to check with individual sites on their handling of these dispensings.

EverNDC.name: EverNDC
EverNDC.description: The EVERNDC table is a lookup table containing all National Drug Codes (NDC) found in the PHARMACY table at the implementing site. That is, pharmacy dispensings occurring at site A will have at least one corresponding record in site A's EVERNDC table but not necessarily any records in site B's EVERNDC table.

columns.name: ndc
columns.definition: The identifier of a drug (or pharmacy product).
columns.valid_values: Any value that may be found in the outpatient fills file at the implementing site.

columns.name: ndc_fda
columns.definition: The original FDA National Drug Code in 4-4-2, 5-3-2, or 5-4-1 format including dashes
columns.valid_values: Any value consisting of numbers and dashes.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Populate only if available in source data; generally this value cannot be derived from the char(11) NDC format.

columns.name: generic
columns.definition: The generic name of the drug
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Convert to all upper case. Remove form, strength, and all other labels.

columns.name: brand
columns.definition: The brand name of the drug
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Convert to all upper case. Remove form, strength, and all other labels.

columns.name: AHFS1 - AHFS7
columns.definition: The American Society of Health-System Pharmacists drug classification code. Store up to seven different AHFS codes across these variables
columns.valid_values: As determined by the AHFS, or null
columns.implementation_guidelines:
This is a proprietary classification scheme, which not every implementing site has licensed. Users should not assume these columns will be populated at every site or for every row.

If code is in the 6 digit format, pad with two zeros at the end of the code.

The seven AHFS fields do not imply a hierarchy, include all available AHFS codes assigned to each NDC in the sequence you prefer.

columns.name: GPI
columns.definition: The Generic Product Identifier drug classification code
columns.valid_values: As determined by Medi-Span
columns.implementation_guidelines:
This is a proprietary classification scheme, which not every implementing site has licensed. Users should not assume this column will be populated at every site or for every row.

Not to be confused with the generic price indicator variable available from vendor FDB

columns.name: unit_of_measure
columns.definition: The unit of measure as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning except for storing values in all upper case
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Example values are 2000, U/4ML, GM/15ML, %/5GM, -400 UNIT

columns.name: strength
columns.definition: The strength of the drug as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning except for storing values in all upper case
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Example values are 99.99%, 9G, 9MCG/0.3ML, 9000 UNIT

columns.name: dosage_form
columns.definition: The form of the drug as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning except for storing values in all upper case
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Example values are VIAL, VIAL PORT, WAFER, WAF, SOLUTION, SOLN SEQ, SPIRIT

columns.name: obsolete_dt
columns.definition: The date this combination of NDC + generic was made obsolete
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date, or null
columns.implementation_guidelines: Populate only if the NDC is later reused for a drug with a different generic name.

columns.name: reinstated_dt
columns.definition: The date this NDC was re-issued/recycled, after being obsoleted
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date, or null
columns.implementation_guidelines: Populate only if the NDC is later reused for a drug with a different generic name.

columns.name: ndc_site_specific_flag
columns.definition: Indicates whether an NDC is a site-specific, non-standard item.
columns.implementation_guidelines: site-specific NDCs include but are not limited to compound drugs, stock items, repackaged drugs and study medications.  Some site specific NDCs are identifiable via a starting set of characters, such as 11111 or 99999, or a term.

comments.title: Creating NDC lists for multi-site projects
comments.comment:
Creating lists of NDCs for multi-site projects is a known hard problem.

Because this file is explicitly defined as idiosyncratic to each implementing site (only NDCs to be found at that site are included) and because the various commercial sources of NDC catalogues are necessarily ignorant of custom NDCs in use at implementing sites (e.g. for compound drugs and custom repackages) there is no single site that should consider itself capable of developing a valid list for use at multiple sites.

For this reason, we recommend a two-step approach for compiling NDC lists.

  1. The lead analyst of a project can first write a distributed program to query the EverNDC tables across sites. They may use generic names, brand names, AHFS codes (if available), or GPI codes (if available) to identify the NDCs in use at other sites.
  2. They can then collate the NDCs identified from all participating sites to compile a final list of NDCs for the study.

comments.title: Compound Drugs
comments.comment: Compound drugs are represented differently in the data across sites. If the drug you are looking for may be a compound drug, please check with individual sites to understand how they are handling these data.

LabResults.name: Lab Results
LabResults.description: The LAB RESULTS table contains the results of laboratory tests performed on patients.

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Unique to each patient at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Used to link people across files within a site. May or may not contain the official local indigenous person identifier (e.g., 'medical record number').

columns.name: test_type
columns.definition: VDW-specific classification of laboratory results.
columns.valid_values: As defined in the excel spreadsheet and matching SAS dataset references, both maintained by the Lab Workgroup

columns.name: stat
columns.definition: Indicates the immediacy of the test.  The intent of this value is to determine whether the test was obtained as part of routine care or as an emergent/urgent diagnostic test.
columns.implementation_guidelines: The default value should be Routine unless the results for that test indicate Expedite or Stat.  If your site does not ever use Stat or Expedite terminology then the value is set to Unknown.

columns.name: loinc
columns.definition: Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes (LOINC) is a universal coding system for laboratory tests and measurements developed by Regenstrief Institute.
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Visit the LOINC website to download the set of LOINC codes defined by Regenstrief.

Not all LOINCs have been mapped to VDW test_types

.

columns.name: pt_loc
columns.definition: Location of the patient when the lab specimen was obtained.

columns.name: result_loc
columns.definition: Location where the result was completed. Particularly whether the lab was completed in a certified laboratory.

valid_values.meaning: Point of care (e.g. home, provider office)

columns.implementation_guidelines:
Code nulls and unknowns as 'L'. There are no missing values.

Result location is used to identify whether the test was completed in a laboratory (e.g., hospital lab, outpatient clinic lab, emergency department lab) or if the test was completed using a point of care device at a location other than a certified laboratory (e.g., anticoagulation clinic, newborn nursery, finger stick in provider office, home.) The information may not be available at all sites.

columns.name: specimen_id
columns.definition: Used to uniquely identify a collected specimen which may ultimately be used to obtain multiple lab results.  Specimen ID will be used to connect multiple records from the same blood sample.
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: A possible way to create Specimen_ID is by concatenating lab accession number and date. At most sites lab accession number is reused, thus concatenating the date will make a unique specimen ID for that test_type. Since date is PHI consider applying a hash. md5(compress(AccessionNumber||SampleCollectionDt)) as Specimen_ID format=$hex32.

columns.name: specimen_source
columns.definition: The source or method for collecting the specimen.

valid_values.meaning: self-swab (similar to NSWAB but with ‘self’ designation)

columns.name: local_cd
columns.definition: The lab test type code as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning. This code indicates in the data source system which test was performed.
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Unique to each site.

columns.name: battery_cd
columns.definition: The battery code as reported in source data without standarization or cleaning. A battery consists of a grouping or series of tests performed and is sometimes referred to as a panel of tests.
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Unique to each site.

columns.name: px
columns.valid_values: As defined in procedures, or null.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Refer to the PX variable on the Procedure table for type and length.

columns.name: px_codetype
columns.definition: Names the scheme of the code found in the px column.
columns.valid_values: As defined in procedures, or null.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Refer to the px_codetype variable on the Procedure table for type and length.

columns.name: order_id
columns.definition: Uniquely identifies the order for this lab test.
columns.valid_values: Any, or null
columns.implementation_guidelines: In the future, may link to a table of orders.

columns.name: order_dt
columns.definition: Date that the lab test was ordered.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date <= lab_dt
columns.implementation_guidelines: It is possible for the order date to be any date from months before the sample was taken (in the case of a recurring test to monitor a chronic condition or drug interaction) to the same day the sample was taken.

columns.name: lab_dt
columns.definition: Date that the specimen was collected.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date

columns.name: lab_tm
columns.definition: Time that the specimen was collected.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS time

columns.name: result_dt
columns.definition: Date that the test was resulted.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS date
columns.implementation_guidelines: This date could be the same day the specimen was collected or any date up to weeks later.

columns.name: result_tm
columns.definition: Time that the specimen was resulted.
columns.valid_values: Any SAS time

columns.name: result_c
columns.definition: The result of the test stored in a character field.  This variable works in conjunction with the Modifier variable.
columns.valid_values: Any non-null
columns.implementation_guidelines:
• Symbols like >, <, >=, <= should be removed.
  • Numeric values stored in this variable should be stored with commas removed allowing the SAS default conversion to numeric to occur.
  • Full ranges are to be placed in this field. Examples of full ranges: 3.4-7.5, 13000-18000. Note that commas and blanks should be removed from ranges and the numbers should be separated with a dash.
  • Comments or notes that are seen in addition to a result value should be recorded in the LAB NOTES table, not in this field.
  • The lab workgroup suggests placing 'SEE LAB NOTES TABLE' in the Result_C field when Result_C does not hold the test result but additional information can be found in the Lab Notes table. Examples follow describing when this situation can arise.
  • Include information where the result has not been parsed out of a long string. (This happened at one site when influenza test results were received from outside labs. The time intensive work of writing code to parse the strings was not performed until the results were needed.)
  • Include long or vague results such as “Low risk for cardiovascular disease”.

columns.name: modifier
columns.definition: Modifies the value stored in the Result_C field.
columns.implementation_guidelines: Any relational operators in the original source data value (e.g., <, >, or =) are reflected in the Modifier variable.  If the source data value is '<5' then the Result_C value is 5 and the Modifier is LT.  If the source data value is 'NEGATIVE' then the Result_C value is NEGATIVE and the Modifier is TX.  If the source data value is numeric (digits with or without decimal) and does not contain an operator, then the Modifier is EQ.  If the Result_C value is a range, as described in the cell above, then the Modifier is RA.

columns.name: result_unit
columns.definition: The units in which the result is reported after basic standardizations have been applied.
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Result unit after applying 1) the standardizations from the table supplied by the Laboratory workgroup and 2) any site specific corrections / standardizations not applicable to all sites.

At the least, the value should be uppercase and left justified.

Only recode equivalent units (e.g., ::example::). Do not convert/recode result_c, normal_low_c or normal_high_c in order to use a more favored unit.

columns.name: result_unit_raw
columns.definition: The units in which the result is reported before basic standardizations are applied.
columns.valid_values: Any

columns.name: normal_low_c
columns.definition: The lowest value still considered normal for this test.   This variable works in conjunction with the Modifier_Low variable.
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Symbols like >, <, >=, <= should be removed. Numeric values stored in this variable should be stored to convert with the SAS 8. informat.

columns.name: modifier_low
columns.definition: Modifies the value stored in the Normal_Low_C field.
columns.valid_values: As defined above for the modifier column, or null.
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Any relational operators in the original source data value (e.g., <, >, or =) are reflected in the Modifier_Low variable.

For numeric results one of the following needs to be true:
  1. Both modifier_low and modifier_high contain EQ e.g. (normal values fall in the range 3-10)
  2. modifier_low contains GT or GE and modifier_high contains blank e.g. (normal values are >3 with no upper boundary)
  3. modifier_high contains LT or LE and modifier_low contains blank e.g. (normal values are <=10 with no lower boundary)

Do not place 0 in the lower boundary unless it comes from the source data.

columns.name: normal_high_c
columns.definition: The highest value still considered normal for this test.   This variable works in conjunction with the Modifer_High variable.
columns.valid_values: Any
columns.implementation_guidelines: Symbols like >, <, >=, <= should be removed. Numeric values stored in this variable should be stored to convert with the SAS 8. informat.

columns.name: modifier_high
columns.definition: Modifies the value stored in the Normal_High_C field.
columns.valid_values: As defined above for the modifier column, or null.
columns.implementation_guidelines: See guidelines for modifier_low above.

columns.name: abn_ind
columns.definition: Indicates whether the test result is abnormal.
columns.implementation_guidelines: If the abnormal indicator is missing do not impute a value. Missing abnormal indicator values should be set to UK.

columns.name: order_prov
columns.definition: Identifies the provider that ordered the lab test.
columns.valid_values: Foreign key into providers.provider

columns.name: ord_dept
columns.definition: The department or specialty in which the order took place.
columns.valid_values: As given in Appendix A2: Dept Values

columns.name: facility_code
columns.definition: A code indiciating the facility, hospital, or clinic in which the lab order originated.
columns.valid_values: Foreign key into facilities

columns.name: row_id
columns.definition: A site specific identifer that enables linkage between the LAB NOTES and LAB RESULTtables.
columns.valid_values: Any, including null.
columns.implementation_guidelines: A non-null value is the signal that more information will be found in free-text form in the lab_notes table.

comments.title: Resulted labs only
comments.comment: If a test is not resulted for whatever reason (e.g. specimen not sufficient, patient did not show), then that test should not appear in the table.

comments.title: Date Columns
comments.comment: Sites may not have all three date variables filled. In most situations order date will be the last choice of dates used when results are being studied. Multi-site programs could apply logic to pull the date first from lab_dt. If missing then pull from result_dt. If missing then the study may want to pull from order_dt.

VitalSigns.name: Vital Signs
VitalSigns.description: The VITAL SIGNS table includes physiological measures taken by health professionals during encounters. Additional measures on anthropometry are also included.

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Unique to each patient at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Used to link people across files within a site. May or may not contain the official local indigenous person identifier (e.g., 'medical record number').

columns.name: measure_date
columns.definition: The date on which these vital signs were measured
columns.valid_values: Any SAS Date

columns.name: measure_time
columns.definition: The time at which these vital signs were measured
columns.valid_values: Any SAS Time
columns.implementation_guidelines: Preferred to be the actual time of measurement but may also be a check-in time

columns.name: enc_id
columns.definition: Foreign key to the ENCOUNTER table uniquely identifying the encounter; unlinkable records should contain null/missing values
columns.valid_values: Unique to each encounter at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Only populate if there is an encounter in the utilization file that can be definitively matched to the vital record

columns.name: enctype
columns.definition: The type of the encounter at which this measure was taken
columns.valid_values: As defined for the enctype column in the utilization encounter table.
columns.implementation_guidelines: If the encounter type is known, please populate even if you are unable to populate ENC_ID

columns.name: ht
columns.definition: The patient's height in inches at this measure
columns.valid_values: Positive real number
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Set to missing if:
  • age = 0 and (ht < 3 or ht > 41)
  • age between 1 and 5 and (ht < 12 or ht > 60)
  • age between 6 and 12 and (ht < 20 or ht > 84)
  • age between 13 and 17 and (ht < 30 or ht > 108)
  • age > = 18 and (ht < 36 or ht > 108)
Only populate if measured at the visit. Do not impute/carry values from other dates.

columns.name: wt
columns.definition: The patient's weight measured in pounds at this measure
columns.valid_values: Positive real number
columns.implementation_guidelines:
Set to missing if:
  • age = 0 and (wt < 0 or wt > 80)
  • age between 1 and 5 and (wt < 9 or wt > 200)
  • age between 6 and 12 and (wt < 20 or wt > 350)
  • age between 13 and 17 and (wt < 25 or wt > 650)
  • age > = 18 and (wt < 50 or wt > 1000)
Only populate if measured at the visit. Do not impute/carry values from other dates.

columns.name: systolic
columns.definition: The systolic blood pressure measured in mmHg of the patient at this time
columns.valid_values: Integer
columns.implementation_guidelines: Set to missing if < 50 or > 300  Only populate if measured at the visit. Do not impute/carry values from other dates.

columns.name: diastolic
columns.definition: The diastolic blood pressure measured in mmHg of the patient at this time
columns.valid_values: Integer
columns.implementation_guidelines: missing if < 20 or > 160 Only populate if measured at the visit. Do not impute/carry values from other dates. Variable name Definition  Type(Len) Values  Implementation Guidelines

columns.name: bp_type
columns.definition: The type of blood pressure taken

columns.name: position
columns.definition: The patient's position for orthostatic blood pressure measurements

columns.name: ht_raw
columns.definition: The height measurement as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning
columns.implementation_guidelines: Examples may include specific values, ranges, or categories

columns.name: wt_raw
columns.definition: The weight measurement as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning
columns.implementation_guidelines: Examples may include specific values, ranges, or categories

columns.name: bmi_raw
columns.definition: The patient's body mass index measurement as reported in source data without standardization, calculation, or cleaning

columns.name: head_cir_raw
columns.definition: The patient's head circumference measurement as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning

columns.name: systolic_raw
columns.definition: The systolic blood pressure measurement as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning
columns.implementation_guidelines: Examples may include specific values, ranges, or categories

columns.name: diastolic_raw
columns.definition: The diastolic blood pressure measurement as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning
columns.implementation_guidelines: Examples may include specific values, ranges, or categories

columns.name: respir_raw
columns.definition: The respirations in breaths per minute measurement as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning

columns.name: temp_raw
columns.definition: The patient's body temperature measurement as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning

columns.name: pulse_raw
columns.definition: The heartbeats per minute measurement as reported in source data without standardization or cleaning

comments.title: Body Mass Index
comments.comment: Body Mass Index (BMI) is not a cleaned variable on the VITAL SIGNS table. Users are recommended to calculate BMI at the time of actual need making use of the VDW Standard Macros.

comments.title: Raw Columns
comments.comment: The RAW variables' primary purpose is for capturing categories or ranges that may be recorded in the system (e.g. for BMI_RAW values like 'overweight', or '25.0-25.9' or for DIASTOLIC_RAW values like 'HYPERTENSION' or '100-109').

SocialHx.name: Vital Signs
SocialHx.description: The SOCIAL HISTORY table contains behavioral measures taken by health professionals during clinic visits, over the telephone, or via questionnaires. These measures include the use of tobacco, alcohol, and illegal drugs as well as sexual behavior and contraceptive use.

columns.name: MRN
columns.definition: Medical record number is the unique patient identifier within a site and should never leave the site
columns.valid_values: Unique to each patient at each site
columns.implementation_guidelines: Used to link people across files within a site. May or may not contain the official local indigenous person identifier (e.g., 'medical record number').

columns.name: contact_date
columns.definition: Date of encounter or date of social history data collection
columns.valid_values: SAS date, missing is not allowed

columns.name: enc_id
columns.definition: Foreign key to the ENCOUNTER table uniquely identifying the encounter; unlinkable records should contain null/missing values
columns.valid_values: SAS date or null

columns.name: education_years
columns.definition: Number of years of education completed recorded as free text
columns.valid_values: Free text, or null

columns.name: sex_active
columns.definition: Whether the person is sexually active

columns.name: sex_female_partner
columns.definition: Whether the person has female sex partners

columns.name: sex_male_partner
columns.definition: Whether the person has male sex partners

columns.name: sex_comment
columns.definition: Comment about the person's sexual activity
columns.valid_values: Free text, or null

columns.name: bc_abstinence
columns.definition: Whether the person uses abstinence as birth control

columns.name: bc_condom
columns.definition: Whether the person uses condoms as birth control

columns.name: bc_diaphragm
columns.definition: Whether the person uses a diaphragm as birth control

columns.name: bc_implant
columns.definition: Whether the person uses an implant as birth control

columns.name: bc_injection
columns.definition: Whether the person uses injections as birth control

columns.name: bc_inserts
columns.definition: Whether the person uses inserts as birth control
